definition:
A grammar is said to be of *Chomsky normal form* if every production has
either of the two forms $$A \to BC \qquad \mbox{ or } \qquad A \to a$$
where $A,B,C$ are non-terminal symbols, and $a$ is a terminal symbol.

Grammars of this sort are context-free, hence they describe context-free
languages. Moreover, given any context-free language not containing the
empty word $\lambda$, there exists a Chomsky normal form grammar which
describes it.
